subject: Enable/Disable PCIe clocks on NVMe drive hot-add/remove
commitMessage:
Enable/Disable PCIe clocks on NVMe drive hot-add/remove

When the BMC detects the hot-add/hot-removal of an NVMe drive on HSBP,
the BMC shall enable/disable the clock to the NVMe drive on the
DB2000 clock buffer to reduce EMI.
In addition fix the issue of addition/removal events not getting
logged in System Event Log.

Tested:
1. DB2000 clock enabling/disabling on hot addition/removal of PCIe
   drives tested with debug cpld image which emulates hot
   addition/removal of drives. Addition/removal verified via ITP.
   DB2000 clock enabling/disabling verified independently via
   i2c-tools from BMC also.
2. SEL log entries on each hot-add/removal verified via redfish
Signed-off-by: Rohit Chandel <rohit.k.chandel@intel.com>
Change-Id: I5c6f8d6cf0b8fb737006b6ca14f2cfcd6a3de27d

Patch Set 1:

Hi All,

Please review the changes for enbaling/disabling of PCIe clocks (provided through DB2000 clock buffer) in response to hot-add/remove of NVMe drives.

Changeset also logs addition or removal entries to SEL logs.

Regards
Rohit

Probably this comment is not required
nit: consistency in commenting style. /* */ can be used everywhere for multi line comments
magic number, please define this using a macro ?
This function was only used for debug purpose. Actual clocks updation is dependent on only the drive presence not on the prev value of clocks. Thus removing this function to optimize code.

suggest you to use std::optional<bitset<MAX_CLOCK_STATUS>> as the return type of the function. In case of read errors, you could simply return a std::nullopt, so that the caller of the function will be able to distinguish between i2c read errors and actual read clockStatus registers.
Not needed as the function is removed. However used in another function.
Please covert this to camelCase. Applicable to other functions too

Min value of uLong is guranteed to be (2^32-1) or greater by cpp standard. Considering server platforms with 64bit datawidth it shall never go out of range.
Let me know if you still feel the need to change implementation.
nit: nvmeAlert. Please change variable names to camelCase everywhere in this file.

Please capture an error message before returning. Also, should we return here? If there are platforms without this pin definition (say they don't support hotplug drives), we could simply log an error and continue with rest of hsbp-manager's activities.
Here too. Please review the entire file and fix the casing issues
nit: can we give a more specific name here? hsbpCpldFd or something?
nit: we could use uin32_t to be explicitly 32 bit
If we close the file here, the future reads using updateClockStatus() are always going to fail. close(file) is not required here.
nit: Shouldn't this be - unable to monitor events on HSBP Alert line ?

Avoid macros whereever possible. Use constexpr.
https://github.com/isocpp/CppCoreGuidelines/blob/master/CppCoreGuidelines.md#es31-dont-use-macros-for-constants-or-functions
lowerCamelCase and make it a static.

here and there are lots of blow. Check naming convention guide line and update this patch set.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#c-coding-style-and-conventions
removed initialization as per suggestion, as default constructor initializes to 0.

nit: You can create some I2C wrappers inspired from here:
https://github.com/openbmc/pfr-manager/blob/master/libpfr/inc/file.hpp

This will simplify the code and error handling.
As discussed, it'll be taken care in the enhancement task where we add entity manager node and/or HSBP Fru logic.
This is to avoid namespace pollution, check https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/236404/what-is-using-namespace-pollution
To avoid confusion using fully resolved name now.

is this always the same? 
Also, avoid using MACROS

Yes, although it'll be made independent by including a node in entity manager and once FRU for HSBP gets implemented. It'll be taken care in the enhancement task.

All references to macros changed to constexpr.
Using fully resolved names to avoid confusion.
Are these always the same for all systems?
Yes. Same applies as explained in prev comment for hsbpI2cBus =4, line 1108.

this does not look right, it skips the last bit.
As I read again, looks like the highest bit is some sort of a flag. So this maybe correct - but please add comments since it looks odd and the reason is is not obvious.

Its standard way to interact with i2c-dev interface.
https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/i2c/dev-interface
logic does not look right - or can be simplified
removed extra (). Logic simplified. Comment added.

should return.
hsbpFd is still used, for example inside line 1320
+1. Also, better to return a status from this init function. If there are errors in cpldReadingInit, then better to avoid the GPIO monitoring logic.

Noted. Instead of return status from init function, now we depend on successful fd opening by init fn. Gpio monitoring logic only starts if init successful.

Also, alert handler now checks if the fd is valid at top level, to take care of runtime issues.

should set hsbpFd = 0 after closing
other places too
0 is also a valid fd so assigning -1 is correct.
nit:return and then no need for else

Is the idea here that you will see this get handled only once? This async_wait will fire on the first read, but if you want to be notified on the following events, you will need to call async_wait again.

You might consider making this portion (the call and the immediate lambda callback) a function call in and of itself. Then hsbpRequestAlertGpioEvents can call it initially to arm it the first time, but then it can call itself from within the lambda to arm it for future events.

First time async_wait calls the handler(nvmeLvc3AlertHandler) and then onwards retriggering async_wait is done in handler after processing the event. The construct is taken as it is from host-error-monitor
Left it global in case someone from outside the file wants to access these two. But on a second thought lets keep them static as suggested by you, unless such requirement arises.

static in hsbpFd = -1;

0 is a valid FD, so it should not be allowed to default to that.

That was my understanding too. But based on a review comment to save cpu cycles left it uninitialized.
The first call in init function(cpldReadingInit) is the open call, and before that we do not use this variable. So whether or not we init the variable it'll get a value from the open call.
this should be declared where it is first used.

if you make this a constexpr std::array<int, statusAllDrives>, the size is built in and the compiler will throw an error automatically if the number of entries does not match the size specified. The you don't need to have the static_assert below.
these should be declared where they are first used.
these should be declared where they are used (in the loops)
it seems like this logic could be inverted to return early on success and then always close(hsbpFd)/hsbpFd=-1 for all errors at the end of the function.

Logic has become a bit interlinked and complex due to one review comment which was to differentiate between DB2000 register read error and DB2000 i2c access issue. We are returning three types of return from updateClocksStatus and each error needs its own error message. At the moment can not think of a better logic.
